Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral dissertation research: Articulating the Past, The Value of Dinosaurs in America, 1870-1930

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Introduction. This grant is to support a research project that will serve to enhance the researcher's doctoral dissertation. The dissertation focuses on the production and circulation of scientific knowledge; one of its key goals is to determine how a wide range of people interacted with fossil dinosaurs in late 19th and early 20th century America. The dissertation consists of three parts. The first is on the acquisition of fossils, focusing on the people and practices associated with collecting dinosaur bones in the field. The second explores how museum curators used fossils to generate new knowledge about the history of life on earth. The final part is about the public's interaction with dinosaurs, both in natural history museums and other sites of amusement such as the cinema or amusement parks. Close attention is paid to constructing a new and appropriate interpretative methodology to understand the construction and "consumption" of knowledge using models of economic exchange.

Intellectual Merit. This award will fund travel to a selected number of museum archives. The goal of these trips is to acquire information that will serve to provide a fresh account of the activities of people brought together by a shared interest in dinosaurs and the diverse ways in which each of them interacted with these objects and one another. The plan is to produce an historical narrative around fossils rather than people, ideas, or practices; doing so will results in a history that cuts across geography, social class, and a range of epistemic concerns. It will also serve to illustrate that science during the early turn 20th century was not just the purview of a small academic elite. On the contrary, many people besides professional paleontologists contributed to the making of new knowledge about dinosaurs. Moreover, an even broader cross section of American culture participated in its consumption. For these reasons, the history of dinosaurs provides a unique opportunity to explore the contested boundary between science and other domains of American culture around the turn of the 20th century.

Potential Broader Impacts. The dissertation explores how expert scientific knowledge was integrated into a broader cultural context. The challenge of doing so is no less urgent today than it was a hundred years ago; global climate change, widespread habitat destruction, and the loss of biodiversity are all problems that cannot be solved by scientists alone. In democratic societies, science relies on a broad base of public interest, involvement, and support. As a result, the project has the potential to help us better understand why it can be so difficult to establish meaningful communication across widely dispersed social and cultural contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Articulating the Past:The Commercial Culture of Vertebrate Paleontology, 1870-1930
This project traced how the ideals, norms, and practices ofindustrialization manifested themselves in the collection, study, anddisplay of fossil dinosaurs.  Its primary goal was to use dinosaurs asa means to explore how science intersected with commercial cultureduring the American Gilded Age and Progressive Era.
During the closing decades of the 19th century, Americanpaleontologists unearthed creatures the likes of which no one had everdreamed, including Brontosaurus, Stegosaurus, Tyrannosaurus, andTriceratops, just to name a few.  These discoveries were a directoutcome of the second industrial revolution.  As geologists scouredcountry¹s interior for mineral resources, they stumbled across fossilsalmost by happenstance.  And at a time when the nation was quicklybecoming the world¹s leading economy, it did not take long fordinosaurs to become a potent symbol of its industrial might and power.Indeed, one of America¹s foremost captains of industry‹AndrewCarnegie‹endowed a natural history museum whose primary goal was todisplay these extinct monsters.  When his curators discovered askeleton measuring over one hundred and twenty feet in length duringthe late 1890s, they even named it Diplodocus carnegii in his honor.
Carnegie was not alone in his fascination with dinosaurs. As wealthyindustrialists coalesced into a coherent social class, they began topatronize elite cultural institutions.  Among other things, they builtlarge and well-funded museums of natural history. Almost immediately,these museums began to compete with one another by racing to excavate,prepare, and display the most spectacular dinosaurs.  In order to doso efficiently, institutions like the American Museum in New Yorkmodeled themselves after industrial corporations.  As they grew insize, they began to employ a small army of salaried managers andinstituted sophisticated bookkeeping techniques.  They also integratedvertically, sending out teams of explorers to collect specimens,publishing their own journals, and establishing in-house preparationlabs for the construction of elaborate displays.
The results of this project will be made public in a number of ways.One article, entitled ³Bringing Dinosaurs Back to Life,² is scheduledfor publication in the September 2012 issue of Isis, the journal ofthe History of Science Society.  Another article, entitled³Prospecting for Dinosaurs on the Mining Frontier,² is currently insubmission at Representations, an interdisciplinary humanities journalpublished by the University of California Press.  Third, adissertation entitled ³Dinosaurs: Assembling an Icon of Science² willbe submitted to Department of the History of Science at HarvardUniversity in August 2012.
